newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL SHARES DIP SHARPLY ON FOREIGN SALES.
newsitem.headline: KL SHARES DIP SHARPLY ON FOREIGN SALES.

text.p: Share prices were sharply lower mid-morning on Monday as foreigners continued to sell local shares, dealers and analysts said.
At 0224 GMT, the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange Composite Index was down 2.05 percent at 913.26 points. Five minutes later, the index was down 2.20 percent or 20.47 points at 911.89.
"There is no reason for anyone to buy local shares. Foreigners are selling as usual and local funds are staying out after Friday's buying," said a dealer with a local brokerage.
"Nothing has changed over the weekend except the ringgit has fallen further," the dealer said.
Analysts said a depressing earnings outlook for companies was also responsible for worsening of the sentiment.
They said further weakening of the currency did not revive interest in stocks because not many local companies were expected to benefit from it.

"Yes, stocks have cheapened for foreigners who want to buy it. But how many foreigners today want to buy stocks (in this region)," said Phua Lee Kerk, head of research at Jupiter Securities in Kuala Lumpur.
He said earnings outlook across many sectors, particularly highly import-dependant automobile business, was looking much weaker than before.
Debutante General Soil Engineering opened at 7.90 ringgit against an offer price of 2.70, but dipped 7.20 ringgit around 0250 GMT.
